title: Web Cache Poisoning on  █████
vulnerability_information:
**Description:**
The web application `https://████████` uses a web cache to more efficiently serve its pages to the users. An attacker can send a malformed request which the server caches the response of and sends it to the users.

## Impact

An attacker can alter the web cache, making the web application unavailable for as long as they wish.

## System Host(s)
█████████

## Affected Product(s) and Version(s)


## CVE Numbers


## Steps to Reproduce
* Send the following request to the server:
```http
GET /yeettest?yeettest=1 HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Host: www.█████
Connection: Keep-alive
yeetheadertest1:
```

* The server will return a 400 status code response and cache the response.
* Now, send the request below. Normally, it should return a 404 response.
```http
GET /yeettest?yeettest=1 HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Host: www.████████
Connection: Keep-alive
```
* However it returns the same response as the previous one, which means that the response was cached.

**Note:** I have done these tests on the path `/yeettest?yeettest=1` in order to not disrupt the experience of the website's users. However, an attacker would use this bug on the main page.

## Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions
Do not cache responses with error-related status codes.

activities.message:
Greetings from the Department of Defense (DoD),

Thank you for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program (VDP).

By submitting this report, you acknowledge understanding of, and agreement to, the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Policy as detailed at @DeptofDefense.

The VDP Team will review your report to ensure compliance with the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Policy.  If your report is determined to be out-of-scope, it will be closed without action.

We will attempt to validate in-scope vulnerability reports and may request additional information from you if necessary. We will forward reports with validated vulnerabilities to DoD system owners for their action.

Our goal is to provide you with status updates not less than every two weeks until the reported vulnerability is resolved.

Regards,

The VDP Team

Greetings,
To validate your report, we require additional information.
Can you please answer the following questions?

…Are you still able to reproduce this, I tired your PoC and even when I sent your 2nd request first I got a 400 not a 404 like you said I should.  Also with the page coming back as a 400 that is most likely the system owner would want as it is not a valid page, if you were getting 200's I'd be more concerned.  Please self close if you are not able to prove you get at least different responses from each request.

If you have any questions, please let me know.
Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.
Regards

Yes, I am still able to reproduce the issue, I have attached a demo as well. If you receive a 404 response while you are expecting a 400, you can just add more Than in the last header and change the path we are sending the request to a completely random one, since once you receive a 404 that response is cached and will be returned regardless of the header(since the header is not a cache key). You are right that the owner would want the server to return 404 or 400 when we send the request to `/yeettest`. However, as I stated in my report, we just use this report in order to not disrupt the web application. We can also use this vulnerability to cache pages that would normally return 200 and make them inaccessible. 

**PS:** Here is the request I am sending once again, it might not worked if you alter the header. 
```http
GET /asdasdasdasdasd?jasdjkasdasdasdasdasdasdasdash=1 HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Host: www.████
Connection: Keep-alive
yeetheadertest1:
```

Greetings,
To validate your report, we require additional information.
Can you please answer the following questions?

… go ahead and do it live on the main application as we do not view this as an issue as it is, this is just a 400 vs a 404 because of the fake header you use.  If you can provide a valid PoC on the live site we can submit this but as is this is not a vulnerability.
If unable to do so please self close as it will not affect your hackerone score.

If you have any questions, please let me know.
Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.
Regards
The server would normally respond to the request with 200, but it responded with a 400 instead since it cached the response with the error code.

Greetings,
To validate your report, we require additional information.
Can you please answer the following questions?

…You still don't appear to be hitting the site itself, you are putting fake host headers in after you get the 200, and repeating 400's which is what we expect for a fake host header.

If you have any questions, please let me know.
Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.
Regards

I do not understand how this can be expected behavior since the server clearly caches responses containing error codes and responds with 400 even to perfectly fine requests that do not contain the fake host header. If you visit the URL https://www.█████/?yeet2=sadasdsad you can see that the servers responds with a 400 even though the request you sent to it was perfectly normal. This is caused by the misconfiguration of the web cache. It should not cache responses with error codes or else this misconfiguration can be used to make the server respond with a 400 in the situations where it should respond normally.

@fr1nge you might be right in that something is not quite working as expected. That does not mean there is a vulnerability however. For instance you said this can cause availability issues. Go ahead and take the server down (not just locally) if able to prove your point. Currently we do not see any exploitable issue, and if you can show one we would be happy to process it. As is though, this is not doing anything concerning. Thank you!

In that case, I will be starting a script that will constantly send requests to the main page and eventually overwrite the cache. I will send another comment once the attack is successful. However, I do not understand what you mean by "not just locally" since the attack clearly is not local, and you too get a 400 response when you visit the URL https://www.██████████/?yeet2=sadasdsad even though you should actually be receiving the main page.

I mean, in this case you are talking DoS. If its just local to you and not affecting the server, it will show 500 errors for you, but noone else. Sounds good on the script- let us know when it works. Thanks!

So my point here is, why would xyz.mil/?yeet2=blah return a 200? It shouldn't be returning a 200 in most cases as that path does not exist. You are talking about 400s vs 404s, which one is saying that does not exist! and the other is saying this request is no good. So when you are switching between the two, the question remains "so what?" What is the vulnerability or issue here? Whether the server is responding with a does not exist or a bad request, either way I do no see a valid exploit that you can use unless it is dumping information from a source where it should not be via the cache, or causing a DoS. I have not seen either- so, we can leave it in needs more information if you want to try the DoS portion, but I don't see a viable exploit here based on any of this. Thanks!

It should return a 200 because we are not editing the path, we are just editing a parameter which the server does not care about, but the cache does. If you change yeet2=blah into something else, you will see that it returns a 200 which is what should happen. The reason I'm using that parameter to demonstrate the vulnerability is because even though the server doesn't care, the parameter is used as a key in the web cache which allows me to demonstrate this vulnerability without waiting for a day.

I think that I finally have a PoC that you will accept as DoS. After trying to overwrite the cache of other pages that the main page links to, I found the link https://www.████████/████████.htm . And sent the request with the malicious header, which returned ```http HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request Server: nginx Date: Tue, 04 May 2021 21:26:30 GMT Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 628 X-Varnish: 2139951 Age: 0 Via: 1.1 varnish-v4 Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff 400 Request Header Or Cookie Too Large

400 Bad Request

Request Header Or Cookie Too Large
nginx
``` And now, if you visit the main page https://www.███/ and click the `██████` on the bottom right, you will see that the page is unavailable due to the cache poisoning. I hope that this PoC is enough to demonstrate the impact of this vulnerability. Kind Regards, @fr1nge
@fr1nge please provide us a page that clearly shows as a 200, and then one that you have made unavailable. Also, if its refreshing every 24 hours....is this really an issue?

Yes, it is clearly an issue since an attacker can make a page unavailable for at least 24 hours and more if they want to using a very simple automation that sends malicious requests everyday at a set time.  I understand that you want me to provide you with a page that returns 200 and then demonstrate that it returns a 400 after the attack. In order to prevent any miscommunication and confusion regarding the next PoC. Could you confirm that the page https://www.██████████/█████ returns a response code of 200?
confirmed
Could you please now revisit the URL https://www.███/███ . It should be returning 400
All good here

This is an example of how this vulnerability can be used to make this website unavailable. So this is proof that it can be used as a DoS. This effect can be extended to more than 24 hours by periodically sending requests to the server. I hope this is a good enough demonstration of this bug's impact. If so, could you please triage it.
Oh wait, sorry about that, I didn't open your screenshot. I meant you said it returned 400. Let me check.

It just went down for me- so confirmed. Good job sticking with it- sorry it took so long, but we need all that goodness/proof to provide to the system owner especially with vulnerabilities like these with such a high false positive.

Greetings,

We have validated the vulnerability you reported and are preparing to forward this report to the affected DoD system owner for resolution.

Thank you for bringing this vulnerability to our attention!

We will endeavor to answer any questions the system owners may have regarding this report; however, there is a possibility we will need to contact you if they require more information to resolve the vulnerability.

You will receive another status update after we have confirmed your report has been resolved by the system owner. If you have any questions, please let me know.

Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.

Regards,

The VDP Team
I noticed that your url bar it says https://█████████/█████ however it should say https://www.███████/████████ could you please try again with the one that has the www.
Thats just what the bar shortens it too (in chrome)- only way to grab the www in the snip is to do a delay :). you are triaged regardless
@fr1nge Can you verify if this is fixed? System Owner has stated they have mitigated this.
I can confirm that the issue is fixed. The System Owner has disabled the web cache.

Good news!

The vulnerability you reported has been resolved and this report is now closed. If you have any further questions or disagree that the report is resolved, please let us know.

Thank you for your time and effort to improve the security of the DoD information network.

Regards,

The VDP Team
Thank you. Could you disclose this report?
Added to the queue- we just did disclosures yesterday, so could be a week or two. Thanks!

Thanks for participating in the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program. We're publicly disclosing your resolved report at this time.  We also lock the report on the disclosure but feel free to reach out to us at VDP-Questions@dc3.mil if there are any questions, concerns or issues.
